dek: How famous people are remembered (or not) after they die.

prelude.value: When a famous person dies, articles are written, tweets are tweeted, and Wikipedia is updated.
We feel the impact of the loss despite likely not knowing them personally.

perspectiveSteps.text: How big of a deal is it? To put this in perspective, let’s look at living icon Beyoncé. Here are her (English) Wikipedia pageviews between March and May of 2016, in 48 hour intervals.
On April 24, Beyoncé dropped Lemonade, and the internet went wild. Her pageviews went from an average of 30 thousand to nearly 300 thousand, a tenfold increase.
And now let’s take a look at Prince, starting with the period leading up to his death.
In the 48 hours after Prince’s death was reported, he accumulated over 11 million pageviews on Wikipedia. It was huge news, and was reflected by the pageviews.
Over 1,300 notable people have died in the last three years, according to Wikipedia. Here are the 84 that saw over half a million pageviews immediately after their death.
Although no one captivated attention quite like Prince, the spikes in pageviews after death can often overshadow major events.

perspectiveNote: Adjusted pageviews are the pageviews scaled to an average day of Wikipedia traffic during the collection period of this data. The remainder of the article will refer to this simply as “pageviews.”

changeIntro.value: It makes sense that big names like Prince and Stephen Hawking get the most traffic. But who saw the greatest increase compared to a typical day?

careCaption: “You live only as long as the last person who remembers you.” — Akecheta Westworld

careIntro.value: The first 48 hours only tell us part of the story. How (and how long) we care for might be a better indicator of the sustained impact of their death. Here are the number of weeks after death until pageviews return to normal.

careNote: A return to normal traffic was considered when the pageviews fell within two standard deviations of the median of the pageviews before the date of death. TBD means they have yet to return to normal.

impactIntro.value: But not everyone’s pageviews do return to normal. Perhaps they were relatively unknown before, and their death increased their visibility. Or maybe there was a renewed interest in their life’s work. Let’s look at the one-week moving average the percent increase in pageviews compared to before death.

impactNote: Only including people with data for at least 120 days after their death.

conclusion.value: Wikipedia traffic to an individual’s page is certainly not the best way to summarize how much people care or are affected. However, it is a good proxy for our behavior to these often unexpectedly tragic events. Quantifying this gives us a glimpse into our collective reactions.

methodText.value: Data for this story were collected and processed using the Wikipedia API. The yearly aggregation of notable deaths (eg. 2018) was the starting point. The full source and reproducible scripts are available on Github. The development of the entire project was streamed from start to finish. Check it out on YouTube.

The period of collection was from July 1, 2015 - July 23, 2018 from English Wikipedia. Only people with at least 30 days of padding from the edge of this range, hit 500k adjusted pageviews the 48 hours after their death, and had a median 48-hour adjust pageviews of 100+ before death were considered. All pageviews were adjusted to represent traffic on an average day during this period to allow for fair comparison across days.
A return to “normal” traffic was considered when the pageviews fell within two standard deviations of the median of the pageviews before the date of death.
